sub_title: Head of Advocacy at the Institute on Statelessness and Inclusion (ISI)
summary:
Change requires leadership, vision and a focus on solutions.

Too many marginalised groups are being subjected to human rights abuses around the world. My work has been to develop rights-based strategies and models and promote change.

I am passionate about working practically to see the principles of international human rights implemented nationally, regionally and internationally, building on my extensive experience on refugee, asylum seeker, statelessness, migrant, LGBTIQ+ and indigenous programs and policy issues globally.

With 20 years of leadership experience in not-for-profit management and governance across 50 countries, my expertise lies in developing strategies for change and organizational development and in advising and problem-solving with civil society, governments and UN bodies.

I am the Head of Advocacy for the the Institute on Statelessness and Inclusion (ISI) which is the first and the only human rights NGO dedicated to promoting the right to a nationality and the rights of stateless people globally. I am also on the Taskforce of The Global Alliance to End Statelessness, a UNHCR initiative that seeks to accelerate solutions to statelessness through a collective multi stakeholder approach, which centres those who are stateless and formerly stateless.

I was the previous Executive Director of Nationality for All, a regional NGO working to advance the rights of people affected by statelessness in the Asia-Pacific region, and was the Executive Director of the International Detention Coalition for 10 years, and a recent fellow at the Centre for Asia Pacific Refugee Studies (CAPRS) at the University of Auckland

I am a social anthropologist and recently completed my doctoral degree with a focus on how civil society can effectively engage governments for rights-based policy change.  

The model of effective engagement I developed as part of this research was called “ a new, original, and potentially life-changing contribution”, and that the research has the “potential to make such an important contribution to how we might understand this particular approach to bringing about policy change”.

My work ahead is to explore supporting communities and civil society groups in their human rights advocacy work using this framework.

My achievements include the Australian Human Rights Award in 2002, and was nominated for the 2004 French Human Rights Prize and the 2017 Trust Law Awards for my work with vulnerable groups in detention.

I am reachable on: grant.mitchell@institutesi.org

[{'title': 'COVID-19 Emergency Statelessness Fund (CESF) Report and Roadmap Advocacy Strategy', 'date': {'start': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2021}, 'end': {'month': None, 'day': None, 'year': None}}, 'description': 'The CESF is a targeted and time-bound initiative
to build a consortium of NGOs and citizenship rights
activists at the frontline of the COVID-19 crisis.
The CESF will implement research-based action
advocacy, to realise structural solutions, challenge
the exclusion of stateless persons, and recognise
and break down the barriers they face', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Grant', 'last_name': 'Mitchell, Ph.D.', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Head of Advocacy at the Institute on Statelessness and Inclusion (ISI)'}]}, {'title': 'Asia Pacific Statelessness Advocacy Strategy ', 'date': {'start': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2019}, 'end': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2021}}, 'description': 'The main causes of statelessness - being nationality laws, policies and practices that discriminate on the basis of gender, ethnicity and religion - are challenges which can and must be addressed.
However, civil society faces limitations in the region, with few groups resourced to address the growing impact of statelessness. In light of this, the Statelessness Network Asia Pacific (SNAP) has emerged as a vital collaborative resource for civil society - the only network focusing on statelessness in the region. SNAP works as both a Secretariat and a coalition to support its members in the following ways:
1. Developing research and resources for evidence-based action
2. Facilitating capacity building
3. Providing technical support

Building on the growing attention and momentum to address statelessness in the region, SNAP is developing an advocacy strategy to see an end to statelessness in the region. SNAP’s 5-year strategy draws from effective change processes to date and identifies key tactics that can be employed to address statelessness in the region. Focusing on 2 key thematic areas - 1. children and 2. gender discrimination; and 2 key populations of concern - the Rohingya and Assam statelessness crises, the strategy outlines actions to be undertaken at the international, regional and national level.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Grant', 'last_name': 'Mitchell, Ph.D.', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Head of Advocacy at the Institute on Statelessness and Inclusion (ISI)'}]}, {'title': 'Ending Child Detention : Global Campaign', 'date': {'start': {'month': 3, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}, 'end': the many detrimental effects that immigration detention has on children, and to encourage states to cease the immigration detention of children consistent with their CRC obligations.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Grant', 'last_name': 'Mitchell, Ph.D.', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Head of Advocacy at the Institute on Statelessness and Inclusion (ISI)'}]}, 'first_name': 'Grant', 'last_name': 'Mitchell, Ph.D.', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Head of Advocacy at the Institute on Statelessness and Inclusion (ISI)'}]}, {'title': 'Monitoring Immigration Detention- A practical guide', 'date': {'start': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}, 'end': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}}, 'description': 'This Monitoring Manual was produced jointly by the UN Refugee Agency (UNHCR), the Association for the Prevention of Torture (APT) and the International Detention Coalition (IDC).

It is a step-by-step guide for anyone or any institution carrying out immigration detention visits. It can also be used as a checklist for authorities, detention centre staff and journalists on the standards that need to be applied when asylum-seekers and migrants are detained.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Grant', 'last_name': 'Mitchell, Ph.D.', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Head of Advocacy at the Institute on Statelessness and Inclusion (ISI)'}]}, {'title': 'Online Detention Toolkit', 'date': {'start': {'month': 4, 'day': None, 'year': 2014}, 'end': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}}, 'description': 'First ever online training module for UN, governments and NGOs around the world on alternatives to immigration detention.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Grant', 'last_name': 'Mitchell, Ph.D.', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Head of Advocacy at the Institute on Statelessness and Inclusion (ISI)'}]}, {'title': 'There are alternatives : a handbook to prevent unnecessary immigration detention', 'date': {'start': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2012}, 'end': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}}, 'description': 'With human migration reaching unprecedented levels, many States are struggling to respond to new refugee, asylum-seeker and migrant arrivals. Current crises highlight the need for alternative approaches that respect fundamental right to liberty, security, and human dignity, while still ensuring that States can responsibly govern their borders.

Over the past five years, the IDC has undertaken a program of research to identify and describe a number of positive alternatives to immigration detention (‘alternatives’) that respect fundamental rights, are less expensive and are equally or more effective than traditional border controls. The IDC has identified over 250 examples of alternatives from 60 countries.

This research, entitled There are alternatives, provides readers with the guidance needed to successfully avoid unnecessary detention and to ensure community options are as effective as possible. The research was launched during the 30th Session of the UN Human Rights Council in Geneva  co-hosted by the Office of the High Commission for Human Rights and the the Permanent Mission of Sweden.', 'contributors': [{'type': 'standardizedContributor', 'first_name': 'Grant', 'last_name': 'Mitchell, Ph.D.', 'name': None, 'headline': 'Head of Advocacy at the Institute on Statelessness and Inclusion (ISI)'}]}, {'title': 'Vulnerability Screening Tool', 'date': {'start': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2016}, 'end': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}}, 'description': 'This screening tool developed on identifying and addressing situations of vulnerability is a UNHCR and IDC collaboration intended to help guide and inform frontline workers and decision-makers on the relevance of vulnerability factors to detention decisions, referrals to alternatives to detention, open reception facilities, community-based placement and support options, in the context of asylum and migration procedures and systems. This screening tool on identifying and addressing situations of vulnerability is a UNHCR and IDC collaboration intended to help guide and inform frontline workers and decision-makers on the relevance of vulnerability factors to detention decisions, referrals to alternatives to detention, open reception facilities, community-based placement and support options, in the context of asylum and migration procedures and systems. The Institute on Statelessness and Inclusion (ISI) is the first and the only human rights NGO dedicated to promoting the right to a nationality and the rights of stateless people globally.

With its mission to work together to counter discrimination and intolerance and promote inclusive societies by realising and protecting everyone’s right to a nationality, ISI is widely regarded as a reliable and expert source of information, convener for the sector, premiere educator, and collaborator.

Central to this work is the strategic leadership and partnership with stateless-led organisations, individuals and NGOs to enlarge the visibility of statelessness and advance its positioning as a human rights issue.

https://www.institutesi.org/', 'title': 'Head of Advocacy', 'employment_type': 'Full-time'}]}, {'company': {'id': 3691, 'name': 'The University of Auckland', 'logo': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/C560BAQFcif2vOtbppQ/company-logo_400_400/0/1645650475717?e=1700697600&v=beta&t=tHyoLqifAB59Xked9JtJtT9zKdrZpPDzk3scmaG91d8', 'url': 'https://www.linkedin.com/school/the-university-of-auckland/', 'employees': {'start': 1001, 'end': 5000}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2021}, 'end': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2022}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Melbourne, Victoria, Australia', 'date': {'start': {'month': 9, 'day': None, 'year': 2021}, 'end': {'month': 8, 'day': None, 'year': 2022}}, 'company': 'The University of Auckland', 'description': 'A fellow at the Centre for Asia Pacific Refugee Studies (CAPRS) at the University of Auckland.
 
The Centre, which launched in 2020, is the first of its kind in the Asia Pacific region and focuses on generating evidence-based and high-impact research to support persons forcibly displaced by climate or conflict-based situations. 

CAPRS has been created with a belief that successful responses to forced displacement require not only robust research but a genuine commitment to translating those findings into impact.

The fellowship provided a unique opportunity to develop my Ph.D. thesis findings on how civil society can effectively and ethically engage governments on human rights issues into an action-oriented policy paper and connected training, to support and build the confidence and capacity of NGOs and affected communities to effectively engage governments as part of their advocacy work.', 'title': 'Postdoctoral Fellow', 'employment_type': None}]}, {'company': {'id': 2981218, 'name': 'Uniting', 'logo': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/C560BAQFgMmNO2ti-sQ/company-logo_400_400/0/1590131013648?e=1700697600&v=beta&t=IL0TLhnGSnnVy6RLbg0OBDmVUid0te04M2S4fyrc0UM', 'url': 'https://www.linkedin.com/company/uniting_nsw-act/', 'employees': {'start': 5001, 'end': 10000}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 12, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}, 'end': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2022}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Melbourne, Australia', 'date': {'start': {'month': 12, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}, 'end': {'month': 7, 'day': None, 'year': 2022}}, 'company': 'Uniting', 'description': 'The largest welfare and community services network in Australia, covering more than 700 services in Victoria and Tasmania across mental health, disability, aged care and early learning, employment, alcohol and drug use and building resilient communities.

We work to inspire people, enliven communities and confront injustice.

At Uniting we work towards achieving a common purpose and share common values. This gives us the ability to be informed by the voice of our consumers and communities to we work alongside to drive real, positive social change.', 'title': 'Board Director', 'employment_type': None}]}, {'company': {'id': 19143509, 'name': 'Nationality for All', 'logo': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/C560BAQFTmQ8MVskxkQ/company-logo_400_400/0/1604982048760?e=1700697600&v=beta&t=bVFAq-BZeDKfCwYJDNa5onFfeTn-l-SV7MUGWt-BfhA', 'url': 'https://www.linkedin.com/company/statelessnessnetworkasiapacific/', 'employees': {'start': 2, 'end': 10}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2019}, 'end': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2021}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Melbourne, Victoria, Australia', 'date': {'start': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2019}, 'end': {'month': 5, 'day': None, 'year': 2021}}, 'company': 'Nationality for All', 'description': 'Nationality for All is a regional NGO that works in partnership with civil society in the Asia-Pacific region to address the impact and root causes of statelessness. Advancing the right to a nationality and fundamental rights for all people affected by statelessness in our region is our priority.

Transitioning from the Statelessness Network Asia Pacific (SNAP), an informal civil society network developed in 2015, Nationality for All is incorporated in Australia and works as a regional NGO continuing SNAP’s goal of promoting collaboration to address statelessness in the region.

Having seen how strategic partnerships can translate into positive impact changes for affected communities, Nationality for All focuses on developing and building upon strategic partnerships in target countries.

My role was to lead and develop the organization into a formal organization based out of Australia which occurred in October 2020, and to support its regional leadership model which occurred in May 2021.

For more information visit: www.nationalityforall.org', 'title': 'Executive Director and Strategic Advisor ', 'employment_type': 'Full-time'}]}, {'company': {'id': 1978295, 'name': 'International Detention Coalition', 'logo': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/C560BAQG60QUd-Bu6lg/company-logo_400_400/0/1592532237221?e=1700697600&v=beta&t=LJLXuu7j2I8-wpaRWxIFUindn_I2I5576ChYY9HaDK4', 'url': 'https://www.linkedin.com/company/international-detention-coalition/', 'employees': {'start': 11, 'end': 50}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2008}, 'end': {'month': 3, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': 'Melbourne, Australia', 'date': {'start': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2008}, 'end': {'month': 3, 'day': None, 'year': 2018}}, 'company': 'International Detention Coalition', 'description': 'Developing and managing the International Detention Coalition (IDC) as an independent and autonomous organisation; including establishing and overseeing financial, legal, governance, human resources, program and administrative systems. 

I oversaw and supported government engagement at the international, regional and national levels in terms of technical advice, guidance, meetings and messaging, with a particular focus on practical implementation of alternatives to immigration detention.

Key achievements: Developed a highly reputable and influential international NGO network spanning 80 countries with more than 300 members.

Worked extensively with UN, academic, NGOs and governments around the world on international human rights standards as they relate to the detention of refugees, asylum seekers and migrants.

Worked successfully with the governments of Belgium, Israel, Japan, Taiwan, Turkey, Greece and elsewhere in seeing law and policy and programs developed to end the detention of children. Impacted UN normative standards on immigration detention for vulnerable populations.', 'title': 'Executive Director', 'employment_type': None}]}, {'company': {'id': 301942, 'name': 'Australian Red Cross', 'logo': 'https://media.licdn.com/dms/image/D560BAQFncGyrjbRNeA/company-logo_400_400/0/1687830892836?e=1700697600&v=beta&t=AdAbvqbqgrK7DL9auQTPtRYZ3RI13QOYcFa6mx-tnwE', 'url': 'https://www.linkedin.com/company/australian-red-cross/', 'employees': {'start': 1001, 'end': 5000}}, 'date': {'start': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2007}, 'end': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2008}}, 'profile_positions': [{'location': None, 'date': {'start': {'month': 1, 'day': None, 'year': 2007}, 'end': {'month': 2, 'day': None, 'year': 2008}}, 'company': 'Australian Red Cross', 'description': 'Managing and developing  all Australian Red Cross  detention, asylum seeker, refugee and international tracing programs , including:
• Immigration Detention Program (Visitation and monitoring of Immigration Detention Centres)
• Community Detention Program (Community care program for vulnerable detainees including women, children and individuals with health issues)
• Asylum Seeker Assistance Scheme (Welfare program for people seeking protection in Australia)
• Community Care Pilot (Welfare program for vulnerable individuals awaiting migration outcomes in Australia)
• International Tracing Program (Assisting individuals regain contact with missing family members affected by conflict)
The role included managing these national programs; overseeing a staff of more than 100; a client load of more than 2,000; developing programs to be responsive to individual need and working closely with the Australian Government on to develop their reception and detention policy for vulnerable individuals.
